hints.label: prop-global-limit-symmetry
hints.title: Global Limit Preserves Translation Symmetry
hints.content:
1354: :label: prop-global-limit-symmetry
1355: 
1356: Consider the Adaptive Gas with ρ-localized fitness potential $V_{\text{fit}}[f_k, \rho]$.
1357: 
1358: **Global limit ($\rho \to \infty$)**: The fitness potential becomes position-independent:
1359: 
1360: $$
1361: \lim_{\rho \to \infty} V_{\text{fit}}[f_k, \rho](x_i, v_i) = V_{\text{global}}[f_k](v_i)
1362: 
1363: $$

hints.label: unlabeled-proof-20
hints.content:
1367: 
1368: :::{prf:proof}
1369: As $\rho \to \infty$, the localization kernel becomes uniform:
1370: 
1371: $$
1372: K_\rho(x_i, x_j) \to \frac{1}{|\mathcal{X}|}
1373: 
1374: $$
1375: 
1376: The localized moments reduce to global averages:
1377: 
1378: $$
1379: \mu_\rho[f_k, Q, x_i] \to \frac{1}{k}\sum_{j \in A_k} Q(x_j, v_j)
1380: 
1381: $$
1382: 
1383: which is **independent of $x_i$**. The Z-scores and fitness potential then depend only on $(x_i, v_i)$ through the raw measurements $R(x_i, v_i)$ and $d_{\text{alg}}(i, j)$, not through the statistical aggregation.
1384: 
1385: For position-independent reward $R(v)$, the fitness becomes:
1386: 
1387: $$
1388: V_{\text{fit}}(x_i, v_i, S) \to \eta^{\alpha+\beta} \exp(\alpha Z[R(v_i)] + \beta Z[d_{\text{alg}}(i, j)])
1389: 
1390: $$

hints.label: conj-localization-symmetry-breaking
hints.title: Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking in the Local Limit
hints.content:
1396: :label: conj-localization-symmetry-breaking
1397: 
1398: In the **local limit** ($\rho \to 0$) with position-independent reward $R(v)$, the Adaptive Gas exhibits **spontaneous symmetry breaking**: even though the dynamics preserve translation symmetry, the quasi-stationary distribution (QSD) develops **spatial structure** (clusters, patterns) that break this symmetry.

hints.label: unlabeled-remark-89
hints.title: When is the Conjecture Expected to Hold?
hints.content:
1438: :class: tip
1439: 
1440: The conjecture is most likely to hold when:
1441: 1. **Strong local coupling**: $\nu / \epsilon_F \gg 1$ (viscous coupling dominates adaptive force)
1442: 2. **Small localization**: $\rho \ll D_{\mathcal{X}}$ (hyper-local statistics)
1443: 3. **Sufficient walkers**: $N \gg 1$ (avoids finite-size effects)
1444: 4. **Periodic boundaries**: $\mathcal{X} = \mathbb{T}^d$ (eliminates boundary artifacts)

hints.label: unlabeled-example-101
hints.title: Pattern Formation via Localization
hints.content:
1450: :class: tip
1451: 
1452: Consider a flat reward $R(x, v) = 0$ (no external bias) on a 2D periodic domain $\mathcal{X} = \mathbb{T}^2$.
1453: 
1454: **Global case ($\rho \to \infty$)**: The QSD is the **uniform distribution** over $\mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{V}$ (maximum entropy).
1455: 
1456: **Local case ($\rho \to 0$)**: The Adaptive Gas can form **spontaneous clusters** at random locations, breaking translational symmetry. The clusters are stabilized by the local viscous coupling (see `07_adaptative_gas.md`, viscous force).

hints.label: thm-anisotropy-transition
hints.title: Isotropy Breaking via Adaptive Diffusion
hints.content:
1464: :label: thm-anisotropy-transition
1465: 
1466: For the Euclidean Gas ($\epsilon_F = 0$, $\nu = 0$, $\epsilon_\Sigma = 0$), the diffusion is **isotropic**:
1467: 
1468: $$
1469: \Sigma_{\text{EG}} = \sigma_v I
1470: 
1471: $$
1472: 
1473: preserving **full $O(d)$ rotational symmetry**.
1474: 
1475: For the Adaptive Gas with $\epsilon_F > 0$ and finite $\epsilon_\Sigma$, the diffusion becomes **anisotropic**:
1476: 
1477: $$
1478: \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x, S) = (H(x, S) + \epsilon_\Sigma I)^{-1/2} \neq \sigma I
1479: 
1480: $$
1481: 
1482: breaking rotational symmetry to the **isometry group** of the Hessian:
1483: 
1484: $$
1485: G_{\text{iso}} = \{R \in O(d) : R^T H(x, S) R = H(x, S)\}
hints.section: ## 5. Symmetry Breaking in the Adaptive Limit
hints.raw_directive:
1461: ### 5.2. Adaptation Strength and Isotropic → Anisotropic Transition
1462: 
1463: :::{prf:theorem} Isotropy Breaking via Adaptive Diffusion
1464: :label: thm-anisotropy-transition
1465: 
1466: For the Euclidean Gas ($\epsilon_F = 0$, $\nu = 0$, $\epsilon_\Sigma = 0$), the diffusion is **isotropic**:
1467: 
1468: $$
1469: \Sigma_{\text{EG}} = \sigma_v I
1470: 
1471: $$
1472: 
1473: preserving **full $O(d)$ rotational symmetry**.
1474: 
1475: For the Adaptive Gas with $\epsilon_F > 0$ and finite $\epsilon_\Sigma$, the diffusion becomes **anisotropic**:
1476: 
1477: $$
1478: \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x, S) = (H(x, S) + \epsilon_\Sigma I)^{-1/2} \neq \sigma I
1479: 
1480: $$
1481: 
1482: breaking rotational symmetry to the **isometry group** of the Hessian:
1483: 
1484: $$
1485: G_{\text{iso}} = \{R \in O(d) : R^T H(x, S) R = H(x, S)\}
1486:

hints.label: unlabeled-proof-142
hints.content:
1489: 
1490: :::{prf:proof}
1491: **Euclidean Gas**: The kinetic operator uses constant isotropic noise $\sigma_v I$. By construction, this is invariant under all orthogonal transformations:
1492: 
1493: $$
1494: R^T (\sigma_v I) R = \sigma_v I
1495: 
1496: $$
1497: 
1498: **Adaptive Gas**: The Hessian $H(x, S) = \nabla^2 V_{\text{fit}}$ generically has **distinct eigenvalues** for complex fitness landscapes. The eigenvectors define **preferred directions** in $\mathcal{X}$.
1499: 
1500: The diffusion tensor $D_{\text{reg}} = (H + \epsilon_\Sigma I)^{-1}$ shares the same eigenvectors as $H$, but with inverted eigenvalues:
1501: 
1502: $$
1503: H u_k = \lambda_k u_k \quad \Rightarrow \quad D_{\text{reg}} u_k = \frac{1}{\lambda_k + \epsilon_\Sigma} u_k
1504: 
1505: $$
1506: 
1507: Only rotations $R$ that **preserve the eigenspaces** of $H$ will leave $D_{\text{reg}}$ invariant.
1508: 
1509: **Isometry group**: The residual symmetry group is:
1510: 
1511: $$
1512: G_{\text{iso}} = \{R \in O(d) : R u_k = u_k \text{ for all eigenvectors } u_k\}
1513: 
1514: $$
1515: 
1516: For generic $H$ with all $\lambda_k$ distinct, $G_{\text{iso}} = \{I\}$ (trivial group), fully breaking rotational symmetry.

hints.label: cor-directional-exploration
hints.title: Anisotropy Induces Directional Exploration
hints.content:
1522: :label: cor-directional-exploration
1523: 
1524: In the Adaptive Gas, walkers explore **more along flat directions** (small Hessian eigenvalues, large diffusion) and **less along curved directions** (large eigenvalues, small diffusion).
